Description of incident: A laptop stolen on or around September 2, 2012 contained current and former patient names, Social Security numbers, and other personal information.  The laptop was taken from the car of a contractor or employee and may have also contained current and former patient mailing addresses, dates of birth, and medical information. Participants in about 50 different research studies that date back an unknown number of years were affected.UPDATE (3/17/2016): Feinstein Institute for Medical Research was fined $3.9 million dollars to settle HIPAA violations by the organization when a laptop that was stolen containing personal information of individuals. The fine was in response to the organizations lack of, or incomplete security management processes which violates HIPAA.More information: http://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2016/03/17/improper-disclosure-research-pa...
